</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Provisions of our amended and restated certificate of incorporation and amended and
	restated bylaws and Delaware law might discourage, delay or prevent a change of control of our company or changes in our management and, as a result, depress the trading price of our common stock.
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our amended and restated certificate of incorporation and amended and restated bylaws contain provisions that could discourage, delay or
	prevent a change in control of our company or changes in our management that the stockholders of our company may deem advantageous. These provisions:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	authorize the issuance of blank check preferred stock that our Board of Directors could issue to increase the number of outstanding shares and to discourage a takeover attempt;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	limit the ability of stockholders to remove directors only &#147;for cause&#148;;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	prohibit our stockholders from calling a special meeting of stockholders;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	prohibit stockholder action by written consent, which requires all stockholder actions to be taken at a meeting of our stockholders;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	provide that the Board of Directors is expressly authorized to adopt, or to alter or repeal our bylaws;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	establish advance notice requirements for nominations for election to our Board of Directors or for proposing matters that can be acted upon by stockholders at stockholder meetings; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	require the approval of holders of at least
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	two-thirds
</FONT>
	of the outstanding shares of common stock to amend the bylaws and certain provisions of the certificate of incorporation.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	These anti-takeover defenses could discourage, delay or prevent a transaction involving a change in control of our company.
	These provisions could also discourage proxy contests and make it more difficult for our stockholders to elect directors of their choosing and cause us to take corporate actions other than those they desire.
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	25
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage27"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290286D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Risks Related to Our Indebtedness
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Our substantial indebtedness could adversely affect our financial health, restrict our activities and affect our ability to meet our
	obligations.
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have a significant amount of indebtedness. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, we had total indebtedness of
	$2,187.6&nbsp;million and we would have been able to borrow an additional $432.2&nbsp;million under the revolving portion of our credit facility, less $17.8&nbsp;million of letters of credit. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, we had no outstanding
	borrowings against the revolving credit facility. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, $1,187.6&nbsp;million of our total indebtedness was associated with Allison Transmission Inc.&#146;s (&#147;ATI&#148;), the Company&#146;s wholly-owned subsidiary, Senior
	Secured Credit Facility Term
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-3
</FONT>
	Loan due 2022 (previously due 2019 and as refinanced in September 2016, the &#147;Term
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-3
</FONT>
	Loan&#148;, and together with the revolving
	credit facility, defined as the &#147;Senior Secured Credit Facility&#148;) and $1,000.0&nbsp;million of our total indebtedness was associated with ATI&#146;s 5.0% Senior Notes due September 2024 (&#147;5.0% Senior Notes&#148;). For a complete
	description of the terms of the Senior Secured Credit Facility and the 5.0% Senior Notes, please see Part II, Item 7, &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations &#150; Liquidity and Capital
	Resources.&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our substantial indebtedness could have important consequences. For example, it could:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	make it more difficult for us to satisfy our obligations under our indebtedness;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	require us to further dedicate a substantial portion of our cash flow from operations to payments of principal and interest on our indebtedness, thereby reducing the availability of our cash flow to fund acquisitions,
	working capital, capital expenditures, research and development efforts and other general corporate purposes;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	increase our vulnerability to and limit our flexibility in planning for, or reacting to, downturns or changes in our business and the industry in which we operate;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	restrict us from making strategic acquisitions or cause us to make
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-strategic
</FONT>
	divestitures;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	expose us to the risk of increased interest rates as borrowings under the Senior Secured Credit Facility are subject to variable rates of interest;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	place us at a competitive disadvantage compared to our competitors that have less debt; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	limit our ability to borrow additional funds.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition, the revolving portion of our
	Senior Secured Credit Facility contains a maximum total senior secured leverage ratio. The Senior Secured Credit Facility and the indenture governing the 5.0% Senior Notes also contains other negative and affirmative covenants that will limit our
	ability to engage in activities that may be in our long-term best interests. Our failure to comply with any of the covenants could result in an event of default which, if not cured or waived, could result in the acceleration of all of our
	indebtedness.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Our ability to pay regular dividends on our common stock is subject to the discretion of our Board of Directors and
	may be limited by our structure and statutory restrictions and restrictions imposed by the Senior Secured Credit Facility and the indenture governing the 5.0% Senior Notes as well as any future agreements.
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our Board of Directors declared a quarterly dividend of $0.06 per share of common stock beginning in the second quarter of 2012, increased the
	quarterly dividend to $0.12 per share of common stock beginning in the second quarter of 2013 and increased the quarterly dividend again to $0.15 per share of common stock beginning in the fourth quarter of 2014. However, the payment of future
	dividends will be at the discretion of our Board of Directors and will depend on, among other things, our earnings, financial condition, capital requirements, level of indebtedness, statutory and contractual restrictions applying to the payment of
	dividends and other considerations that our Board of Directors deems relevant. The Senior Secured Credit Facility and the indenture governing the 5.0% Senior Notes also effectively limit our ability to pay dividends. As a consequence of these
	limitations and restrictions, we may not be able to make, or may have to reduce or eliminate, the payment of dividends on our common stock. Accordingly, you may have to sell some or all of your common stock after price appreciation in order to
	generate cash flow from your investment. You may not receive a gain on your investment when you sell your common stock and you may lose the entire amount of the investment. Additionally, any change in the level of our dividends or the suspension of
	the payment thereof could adversely affect the market price of our common stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	26
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage28"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290286D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	To service our indebtedness, we will require a significant amount of cash and our ability
	to generate cash depends on many factors beyond our control.
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our ability to make cash payments on our indebtedness and to fund
	planned capital expenditures will depend on our ability to generate significant operating cash flow in the future. This, to a significant extent, is subject to general economic, financial, competitive, legislative, regulatory and other factors that
	are beyond our control.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We cannot ensure that our business will generate sufficient cash flow from operations or that future borrowings
	will be available to us under the Senior Secured Credit Facility in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our indebtedness or to fund our other liquidity needs. In such circumstances, we may need to refinance all or a portion of our indebtedness
	on or before maturity. We cannot ensure that we will be able to refinance any of our indebtedness on commercially reasonable terms or at all. If we cannot service our indebtedness, we may have to take actions such as selling assets, seeking
	additional equity or reducing or delaying capital expenditures, strategic acquisitions, investments and alliances. We cannot ensure that any such actions, if necessary, could be effected on commercially reasonable terms or at all.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	If we are unable to generate sufficient cash flow or are otherwise unable to obtain funds necessary to meet required payments of principal,
	premium, if any, and interest on our indebtedness, or if we otherwise fail to comply with the various covenants in the instruments governing our indebtedness, we could be in default under the terms of the agreements governing such indebtedness. In
	the event of such default, the holders of such indebtedness could elect to declare all the funds borrowed thereunder to be due and payable, together with accrued and unpaid interest, the lenders under the Senior Secured Credit Facility could elect
	to terminate their commitments thereunder, cease making further loans and institute foreclosure proceedings against our assets, and we could be forced into bankruptcy or liquidation. If our operating performance declines, we may in the future need
	to obtain waivers from the required lenders under the Senior Secured Credit Facility to avoid being in default. If we or any of our subsidiaries breach the covenants under the Senior Secured Credit Facility and seek a waiver, we may not be able to
	obtain a waiver from the required lenders. If this occurs, we would be in default under the Senior Secured Credit Facility, the lenders could exercise their rights, as described above, and we could be forced into bankruptcy or liquidation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Despite current indebtedness levels, we and our subsidiaries may still be able to incur additional indebtedness, which could further
	exacerbate the risks associated with our substantial financial leverage.
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We and our subsidiaries may be able to incur additional
	indebtedness in the future because the terms of our indebtedness do not fully prohibit us or our subsidiaries from doing so. Subject to covenant compliance and certain conditions, our indebtedness permits additional borrowing, including total
	borrowing up to $432.2&nbsp;million under the revolving portion of the Senior Secured Credit Facility. If new debt is added to our current debt levels and our subsidiaries&#146; current debt levels, the related risks that we and they now face could
	intensify.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	27
</P>

	Indiana 46222. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, we have a total of 17 manufacturing and certain other facilities in seven countries. The following table sets forth certain information regarding these facilities.

	Customization&nbsp;&amp; Distribution

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We believe all our facilities are suitable for their intended purpose, are being efficiently utilized and
	provide adequate capacity to meet demand for the next several years. The table above does not include sales offices located in various countries.
</P>
</EFX_PROPERTIES>

	&nbsp;

<EFX_LEGAL_PROCEEDINGS>
<A NAME="FIS_LEGAL_PROCEEDINGS"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<A NAME="D290286D10K_HTM_TX290286_6">
</A>
	ITEM&nbsp;3.&nbsp;Legal
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Proceedings
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We are subject to various contingencies, including routine legal
	proceedings and claims arising out of the normal course of business. These proceedings primarily involve commercial claims, product liability claims, personal injury claims and workers&#146; compensation claims. The outcome of these lawsuits, legal
	proceedings and claims cannot be predicted with certainty. Nevertheless, we believe the outcome of any of these currently existing proceedings, even if determined adversely, would not have a material adverse effect on our financial condition or
	results of operations.
</P>
</EFX_LEGAL_PROCEEDINGS>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	$
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
	0.15
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Holders
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of February&nbsp;8, 2017, there were approximately 38,560 stockholders of record of our common stock, which includes the actual number of
	holders registered on the books of the Company and holders of shares in &#147;street name&#148; or persons, partnerships, associations, corporations or other entities identified in security position listings maintained by depositories.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Dividends
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our Board of Directors
	declared a quarterly dividend of $0.15 per share each quarter during 2016 and 2015. We expect to continue paying cash dividends on a quarterly basis; however, future dividends are subject to approval of the Board of Directors and may be adjusted as
	business needs or market conditions change. In addition, our Senior Secured Credit Facility and the indenture governing the 5.0% Senior Notes restrict the payment of dividends under certain circumstances.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Unregistered Sales of Securities
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During
	the period covered by this Annual Report on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K,
</FONT>
	we did not offer or sell any securities that were not registered under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the &#147;Securities Act&#148;).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	29
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage31"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290286D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On October&nbsp;30, 2014, our Board of Directors authorized us to repurchase up to $500.0&nbsp;million of our common stock pursuant to a stock
	repurchase program (&#147;2014 Repurchase Program&#148;). We completed the $500.0&nbsp;million of authorized repurchases under the 2014 Repurchase Program in November 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;14, 2016, our Board of Directors authorized us to repurchase up to an additional $1,000.0&nbsp;million of our common stock
	pursuant to a stock repurchase program (&#147;2016 Repurchase Program&#148;). The terms of the 2016 Repurchase Program provide that we may repurchase shares of our common stock, from time to time depending on market conditions and corporate needs,
	in the open market or through privately negotiated transactions in accordance with Rule
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10b-18
</FONT>
	of the Exchange Act. Unless earlier terminated by our Board of Directors, the 2016 Repurchase Program will expire
	on December&nbsp;31, 2019.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table sets forth information related to our repurchase of our common stock on a monthly basis in
	the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2016:
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Comparative Stock Performance Graph
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The information included under the heading &#147;Comparative Stock Performance Graph&#148; in this Item 5 of Part II of this Annual Report on
	Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K
</FONT>
	shall not be deemed to be &#147;soliciting material&#148; or subject to Regulation 14A or 14C, shall not be deemed &#147;filed&#148; for purposes of Section&nbsp;18 of the Exchange Act, or otherwise
	subject to the liabilities of that section, nor shall it be deemed incorporated by reference in any filing under the Securities Act or the Exchange Act.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Set forth below is a graph comparing the total cumulative returns of ALSN, the S&amp;P 500 Index and an index of peer companies selected by
	us. Our peer group includes Donaldson Company Inc., Graco Inc., Roper Technologies Inc., Gentex Corporation, Rockwell Automation Inc. and Sensata Technologies Holding N.V. The graph assumes $100 was invested on March&nbsp;15, 2012 in our common
	stock and each of the indices and that all dividends, if any, are reinvested.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<A NAME="FIS_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<A NAME="D290286D10K_HTM_TX290286_11">
</A>
	ITEM&nbsp;7. Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and
	Results of Operations
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	The following discussion contains forward-looking statements regarding industry trends, our expectations
	regarding our future performance, liquidity and capital resources and other
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-historical
</FONT>
	statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results may differ materially from those discussed in or
	implied by the forward looking statements as a result of various factors, including, without limitation, those set forth under Part I, Item 1A, &#147;Risk Factors,&#148; and other matters included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K.
</FONT>
	The following discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements and the notes thereto included elsewhere in
	this Annual Report on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K,
</FONT>
	as well as the information presented under Part II, Item 6 of this Annual Report on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K.
</FONT>
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Overview
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We design and manufacture
	commercial and defense fully-automatic transmissions. The business was founded in 1915 and has been headquartered in Indianapolis, Indiana since inception. Allison was an operating unit of Old GM from 1929 until 2007, when Allison once again became
	a stand-alone company. In March 2012, Allison began trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol, &#147;ALSN&#148;.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have
	approximately 2,600 employees and 13 different transmission product lines. Although approximately 78% of revenues were generated in North America in 2016, we have a global presence by serving customers in Europe, Asia, South America and Africa. We
	serve customers through an independent network of approximately 1,400 independent distributor and dealer locations worldwide.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Recent Developments
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;3, 2017, we entered into a stock repurchase agreement with ValueAct Capital Master Fund, L.P., a related party, to
	repurchase 10,525,204 shares of our common stock for approximately $363.1&nbsp;million. The purchase was funded with cash on hand and borrowings under the revolving credit facility, and the shares were subsequently retired. Subsequent to the
	transaction, we remain in compliance with the maximum senior secured leverage ratio covenant requirement under ATI&#146;s Senior Secured Credit Facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Trends Impacting Our Business
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our net
	sales are driven by commercial vehicle production, which tends to be highly correlated to macroeconomic conditions. The 2016 reductions in North America
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	On-Highway,
</FONT>
	global
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Off-Highway
</FONT>
	and Service Parts, Support Equipment and Other end markets net sales are consistent with tempering demand conditions in the North America
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	On-Highway
</FONT>
	end
	market and the previously contemplated impact of low energy and commodity prices.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	North America
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	On-Highway
</FONT>
	end market net sales were down 9% for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, principally driven by lower demand for Rugged Duty Series and Highway Series, partially offset by higher demand for Pupil Transport/Shuttle models.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	North America Hybrid-Propulsion Systems for Transit Bus end market net sales were down 16% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared
	to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, principally driven by lower demand due to engine emissions improvements and other alternative technologies.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	North America
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Off-Highway
</FONT>
	end market net sales were down 87% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016
	compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, principally driven by the previously contemplated impact of low energy prices.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	33
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage35"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290286D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Defense end market net sales were up 2% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, principally driven by higher demand for Wheeled Defense, partially offset by lower demand for Tracked Defense.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Outside North America
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	On-Highway
</FONT>
	end market net sales were up 16% for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2016 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, principally driven by higher demand in Europe and Japan, partially offset by lower demand in China.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Outside North America
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Off-Highway
</FONT>
	end market net sales were down 66% for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, principally driven by lower demand in the mining and energy sectors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Service parts, support equipment&nbsp;&amp; other end market net sales were down 3% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, principally driven by lower demand for North America
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Off-Highway
</FONT>
	service parts.
</P>
<EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<A NAME="FIS_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Key Components of our Results of Operations
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Net sales
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We
	generate our net sales primarily from the sale of transmissions, transmission parts, support equipment, defense kits, engineering services, royalties and Extended Transmission Coverage to a wide array of OEMs, distributors and the U.S. government.
	Sales are recorded net of provisions for customer allowances and other rebates. Engineering services are recorded as net sales in accordance with the terms of the contract. The associated costs are recorded in cost of sales. We also have royalty
	agreements with third parties that provide net sales as a result of joint efforts in developing marketable products.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Cost of sales
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our primary components of cost of sales are purchased parts, the overhead expense related to our manufacturing operations and
	direct labor associated with the manufacture and assembly of transmissions and parts. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, direct material costs were approximately 67%, overhead costs were approximately 26% and direct labor costs were
	approximately 7% of total cost of sales. We are subject to changes in our cost of sales caused by movements in underlying commodity prices. We seek to hedge against this risk by using commodity swap contracts and LTSAs. See Part II, Item 7A,
	&#147;Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk&#151;Commodity Price Risk&#148; included in this Annual Report on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Selling, general and administrative
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The principal components of our selling, general and administrative expenses are salaries and benefits for our office personnel, advertising
	and promotional expenses, product warranty expense, expenses relating to certain information technology systems and amortization of our intangibles.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Engineering &#151; research and development
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We incur costs in connection with research and development programs that are expected to contribute to future earnings. Such costs are expensed
	as incurred.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	34
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage36"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290286D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-GAAP
</FONT>
	Financial Measures
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We use Adjusted Earnings before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization (&#147;EBITDA&#148;) and Adjusted EBITDA margin to measure our
	operating profitability. We believe that Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA margin provide management, investors and creditors with useful measures of the operational results of our business and increase the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	period-to-period
</FONT>
</FONT>
	comparability of our operating profitability and comparability with other companies. Adjusted EBITDA margin is also used in the calculation of management&#146;s incentive compensation
	program. The most directly comparable GAAP measure to Adjusted EBITDA is Net income. Adjusted EBITDA is calculated as the earnings before interest expense, income tax expense, amortization of intangible assets, depreciation of property, plant and
	equipment and other adjustments as defined by our Senior Secured Credit Facility. Adjusted EBITDA margin is calculated as Adjusted EBITDA divided by net sales.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We use Adjusted free cash flow to evaluate the amount of cash generated by our business that, after the capital investment needed to maintain
	and grow our business and certain mandatory debt service requirements, can be used for repayment of debt, stockholder distributions and strategic opportunities, including investing in our business and strengthening our balance sheet. We believe that
	Adjusted free cash flow enhances the understanding of the cash flows of our business for management, investors and creditors. Adjusted free cash flow is also used in the calculation of management&#146;s incentive compensation program. The most
	directly comparable GAAP measure to Adjusted free cash flow is Net cash provided by operating activities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following is a
	reconciliation of Net income to Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA margin and a reconciliation of Net cash provided by operating activities to Adjusted free cash flow:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

</P>
</TD>

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(c)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Represents expenses of $3.9&nbsp;million (recorded in Selling, general and administrative) and payments of $3.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, directly associated with stockholder activism
	activity including the notice, and subsequent withdrawal, of director nomination and governance proposals by Ashe Capital Management, LP.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mark-to-market
</FONT>
</FONT>
	of our commodity hedge contracts.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	(e)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Represents adjustments (recorded in Selling, general and administrative) associated with the Dual Power Inverter Module (&#147;DPIM&#148;) extended coverage program liability. The DPIM liability will continue to be
	reviewed for any changes in estimates as additional claims data and field information become available.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-development
</FONT>
	agreements to expand our position in transmission technologies.
</TD>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Net sales
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net sales for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 were $1,840.2&nbsp;million compared to $1,985.8&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, a decrease of 7%. The decrease was principally driven by a $97.0&nbsp;million, or 9%, decrease in net sales in the North America
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	On-Highway
</FONT>
	end market driven by lower demand from Rugged
	Duty Series and Highway Series models partially offset by higher demand for Pupil Transport/Shuttle models, a $48.0&nbsp;million, or 87%, decrease in net sales in the North American
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Off-Highway
</FONT>
	end market
	driven by the previously contemplated impact of low energy prices, a $23.0&nbsp;million, or 66%, decrease in net sales in the Outside North America
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Off-Highway
</FONT>
	end market driven by lower demand in the mining
	and energy sectors, a $12.0&nbsp;million, or 16%, decrease in net sales in the North America Hybrid-Propulsion Systems for Transit Bus end market driven by lower demand due to engine emissions improvements and other alternative technologies, and an
	$11.0&nbsp;million, or 3%, decrease in net sales in the Service Parts, Support Equipment and Other end market driven by lower demand for North America
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Off-Highway
</FONT>
	service parts, partially offset by a
	$43.0&nbsp;million, or 16%, increase in net sales in the Outside North America
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	On-Highway
</FONT>
	end market driven by higher demand in Europe and Japan partially offset by lower demand in China and a
	$2.0&nbsp;million, or 2%, increase in net sales in the Defense end market principally driven by higher demand for Wheeled Defense partially offset by lower demand for Tracked Defense. See &#147;Trends Impacting Our Business&#148; above for
	additional information on net sales by end markets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Cost of sales
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cost of sales for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $976.0&nbsp;million compared to $1,052.0&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, a decrease of 7%. The decrease was principally driven by $51.0&nbsp;million of decreased direct material costs and $22.0&nbsp;million of lower manufacturing expense, in each case consistent with historical trends and
	management&#146;s expectations given the respective change in sales volume, and $10.0&nbsp;million of favorable direct material costs, partially offset by $7.0&nbsp;million of higher incentive compensation expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	37
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage39"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290286D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Gross profit
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Gross profit for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $864.2&nbsp;million compared to $933.8&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, a decrease of 7%. The decrease was principally driven by $98.0&nbsp;million related to decreased net sales and $7.0&nbsp;million of higher incentive compensation expense, partially offset by $22.0&nbsp;million of lower
	manufacturing expense commensurate with decreased net sales, $10.0&nbsp;million of favorable direct material costs and $3.0&nbsp;million resulting from price increases on certain products. Gross profit as a percent of net sales was flat for the year
	compared to 2015 principally driven by favorable direct material costs and price increases on certain products, offset by unfavorable sales volume and higher incentive compensation expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Selling, general and administrative
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Selling, general and administrative for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 were $323.9&nbsp;million compared to $317.1&nbsp;million for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, an increase of 2%. The increase was principally driven by $14.5&nbsp;million of higher incentive compensation expense, $3.9&nbsp;million of stockholder activism expenses and $3.4&nbsp;million of unfavorable
	adjustments related to the DPIM extended coverage program, partially offset by $4.7&nbsp;million of lower product warranty expense, $4.6&nbsp;million of lower intangible asset amortization, $2.2&nbsp;million of unfavorable 2015 product warranty
	adjustments and reduced global commercial spending activities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Engineering &#151; research and development
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Engineering expenses for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 were $88.8&nbsp;million compared to $92.5&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, a decrease of 4%. The decrease was principally driven by the cadence of certain product initiatives, partially offset by $3.2&nbsp;million of higher incentive compensation expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Trade name impairment
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the fourth quarter of 2015, we recorded a trade name impairment charge of $80.0&nbsp;million as a result of lower forecasted net sales
	for certain of our end markets. Refer to NOTE 5, &#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets&#148; in Part II, Item 8, of this Annual Report on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K.
</FONT>
	No trade name impairment charges were recorded in 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Environmental remediation
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the third quarter of 2015, we recorded approximately $14.0&nbsp;million for environmental remediation expenses as a result of the EPA
	determining that GM&#146;s environmental remediation activities at our Indianapolis, Indiana manufacturing facilities were complete, and our assumption of responsibility for future operating, monitoring and maintenance activities. Refer to NOTE 17
	&#147;Commitments and Contingencies&#148; in Part II, Item 8, of this Annual Report on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Loss associated with impairment of long-lived assets
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the first quarter of 2015, we recorded approximately $1.3&nbsp;million of losses associated with impairment of certain of our long-lived
	assets related to the production of the H3000 and H4000 hybrid-propulsion systems.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Interest expense, net
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Interest expense, net for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $100.9&nbsp;million compared to $114.5&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, a decrease of 12%. The decrease was principally driven by $13.7&nbsp;million of favorable
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mark-to-market
</FONT>
</FONT>
	adjustments for our interest rate
	derivatives, $9.3&nbsp;million of lower interest expense as a result of the repurchase and redemption of ATI&#146;s 7.125% Senior Notes in the second quarter of 2015, $8.1&nbsp;million of lower interest expense on ATI&#146;s Term
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-3
</FONT>
	Loan due primarily to the repayment of $1,200&nbsp;million of principal in the third quarter of 2016, and $1.2&nbsp;million of lower amortization of deferred financing fees, partially offset by
	$13.6&nbsp;million of interest expense on ATI&#146;s 5.0% Senior Notes issued in September 2016 and $6.5&nbsp;million of interest expense for our interest rate derivatives that became effective in August 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Expenses related to long-term debt refinancing
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In September 2016, we refinanced our Senior Secured Credit Facility, resulting in expenses of $11.7&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2016. In April 2015, we completed a cash tender offer to purchase any and all of the outstanding 7.125% Senior Notes. The tender offer resulted in the repurchase of $420.9&nbsp;million of the 7.125% Senior Notes in April 2015. In
	May 2015, we redeemed the remaining $50.4&nbsp;million of the outstanding 7.125% Senior Notes, resulting in premiums and expenses totaling $25.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	38
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage40"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290286D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Other income (expense), net
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other income (expense), net for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $2.4&nbsp;million compared to ($0.3) million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015. The change was principally driven by $3.1&nbsp;million of net gains on derivative contracts and $1.1&nbsp;million of lower foreign exchange losses on intercompany financing, partially offset by $1.0&nbsp;million of
	technology-related investment expense and $0.5&nbsp;million of miscellaneous expense, net.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Income tax expense
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Income tax expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $126.4&nbsp;million compared to $106.5&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, resulting in an effective tax rate of 37% for each of the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	39

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Net sales
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net sales for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 were $1,985.8&nbsp;million compared to $2,127.4&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, a decrease of 7%. The decrease was principally driven by a $55.0&nbsp;million, or 12%, decrease in net sales of parts and other products principally driven by lower demand for North American service parts, a
	$46.0&nbsp;million, or 57%, decrease in net sales of Outside North America
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	off-highway
</FONT>
	products principally driven by lower demand from the energy and mining sectors, a $45.0&nbsp;million, or 45%, decrease in
	net sales of North American
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	off-highway
</FONT>
	products principally driven by lower demand from hydraulic fracturing applications, a $44.0&nbsp;million, or 28%, decrease in net sales of defense products driven by
	lower U.S. defense spending and the recognition of previously deferred revenue in 2014 related to shipment of certain tracked transmissions at the request of the U.S. government, a $20.0&nbsp;million, or 22%, decrease in net sales of North America
	hybrid-propulsion systems for transit buses driven by lower demand due to engine emissions improvements and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-hybrid
</FONT>
	alternatives that generally require a fully-automatic transmission, and a
	$2.0&nbsp;million, or 1%, decrease in net sales of Outside North America
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	on-highway
</FONT>
	products principally driven by lower demand in China partially offset by higher demand in Europe, partially offset by a
	$71.0&nbsp;million, or 7%, increase in net sales of North American
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	on-highway
</FONT>
	products principally driven by higher demand from Rugged Duty Series and Highway Series models.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Cost of sales
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cost of sales for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $1,052.0&nbsp;million compared to $1,151.5&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, a decrease of 9%. The decrease was principally driven by approximately $59.0&nbsp;million of decreased direct material costs commensurate with decreased sales, $14.0&nbsp;million of favorable direct material costs,
	$7.5&nbsp;million of lower incentive compensation expense, and lower manufacturing cost commensurate with decreased sales and consistent with historical trends and management&#146;s expectations given the respective change in sales volume.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Gross profit
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Gross profit for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $933.8&nbsp;million compared to $975.9&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, a decrease of 4%. The decrease was principally driven by $93.0&nbsp;million related to decreased sales volume and $1.0&nbsp;million of unfavorable foreign exchange, partially offset by $26.0&nbsp;million resulting from price
	increases on certain products, $14.0&nbsp;million of favorable material costs, $7.5&nbsp;million of lower incentive compensation expense and $5.0&nbsp;million of lower depreciation expense. Gross profit as a percentage of net sales increased 1%,
	principally driven by price increases on certain products and favorable material costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	40
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage42"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290286D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Selling, general and administrative
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Selling, general and administrative expenses for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 were $317.1&nbsp;million compared to $344.6&nbsp;million
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, a decrease of 8%. The decrease was principally driven by $9.6&nbsp;million of lower incentive compensation expense, $4.4&nbsp;million of lower stock-based compensation expense, a $3.1&nbsp;million favorable
	adjustment related to the DPIM extended coverage program, $1.7&nbsp;million of lower intangible asset amortization and reduced global commercial spending activities.
<B>
<I>
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Engineering &#151; research and development
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Engineering expenses for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 were $92.5&nbsp;million compared to $103.8&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, a decrease of 11%. The decrease was principally driven by $5.9&nbsp;million of lower technology-related license expenses to expand our position in transmission technologies, $4.2&nbsp;million of lower incentive compensation
	expense and decreased product initiatives spending.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Trade name impairment
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the fourth quarter of 2015, we recorded a trade name impairment charge of $80.0&nbsp;million as a result of lower forecasted net sales
	for certain of our end markets. Refer to NOTE 5, &#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets&#148; in Part II, Item 8, of this Annual Report on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Environmental remediation
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the third quarter of 2015, we recorded approximately $14.0&nbsp;million for environmental remediation expenses as a result of the EPA
	determining that GM&#146;s environmental remediation activities at our Indianapolis, Indiana manufacturing facilities were complete, and our assumption of responsibility for future operating, monitoring and maintenance activities. Refer to NOTE 17
	&#147;Commitments and Contingencies&#148; in Part II, Item 8, of this Annual Report on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Loss associated with impairment of long-lived assets
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the first quarter of 2015 and the fourth quarter of 2014, we recorded approximately $1.3&nbsp;million and $15.4&nbsp;million,
	respectively, of losses associated with impairment of certain of our long-lived assets related to the production of the H3000 and H4000 hybrid-propulsion systems.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Interest expense, net
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Interest expense, net for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $114.5&nbsp;million compared to $138.4&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, a decrease of 17%. The decrease was principally driven by $24.3&nbsp;million of lower interest expense as a result of the repurchase and redemption of ATI&#146;s 7.125% Senior Notes during the second quarter of 2015,
	$18.8&nbsp;million of lower interest expense as a result of the maturity of $950.0&nbsp;million of interest rate derivatives, $5.5&nbsp;million of lower interest expense as a result of debt repayments, $3.9&nbsp;million of lower interest expense as
	a result of lower interest rates and $0.9&nbsp;million of lower amortization of deferred financing charges, partially offset by $17.5&nbsp;million of unfavorable
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mark-to-market
</FONT>
</FONT>
	adjustments for our interest rate derivatives and $11.8&nbsp;million of higher interest expense as a result of the addition of $470.0&nbsp;million to
	ATI&#146;s Term
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-3
</FONT>
	Loan in April 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Premiums and expenses on tender offer and
	redemption of long-term debt
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In April 2015, we completed a cash tender offer to purchase any and all of ATI&#146;s outstanding
	7.125% Senior Notes. The tender offer resulted in the repurchase of $420.9&nbsp;million of the 7.125% Senior Notes in April 2015. In May 2015, we redeemed the remaining $50.4&nbsp;million of the outstanding 7.125% Senior Notes, resulting in premiums
	and expenses of $25.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Other expense, net
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other expense, net for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $0.3&nbsp;million compared to $5.6&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, a decrease of 95%. The decrease was principally driven by $3.6&nbsp;million of lower foreign exchange losses on intercompany financing, a $2.9&nbsp;million gain as a result of a vendor settlement, $2.4&nbsp;million of gains
	related to foreign exchange, $2.0&nbsp;million of 2014 losses on impairment of technology-related investments, $1.4&nbsp;million of 2014 public offering fees and expenses, and $0.2&nbsp;million of lower expenses related to debt repayments, partially
	offset by $2.6&nbsp;million of 2014 cost-share grant program income, $2.2&nbsp;million of higher expenses related to unrealized and realized losses on derivative contracts, a $2.0&nbsp;million 2014 gain related to the negotiation of a commercial
	agreement and $0.4&nbsp;million of higher miscellaneous expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	41
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage43"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Income tax expense
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Income tax expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $106.5&nbsp;million compared to $139.5&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, resulting in effective tax rates of 37% and 38% for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	42

<A HREF="#D290286D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We generate cash primarily from operations to fund our operating, investing and financing activities. Our principal uses of cash are operating
	expenses, capital expenditures, debt service, stock repurchases, dividends on common stock and working capital needs. We had total available cash and cash equivalents of $204.7&nbsp;million and $251.6&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and
	2015, respectively. Of the available cash and cash equivalents, approximately $123.5&nbsp;million and $151.6&nbsp;million were deposited in operating accounts while approximately $81.2&nbsp;million and $100.0&nbsp;million were invested in U.S.
	government backed securities as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the total of cash and
	cash equivalents held by foreign subsidiaries was $56.7&nbsp;million, the majority of which was located in Europe and China. The geographic location of our cash aligns with our business growth strategy. We manage our worldwide cash requirements
	considering available funds among the subsidiaries through which we conduct our business and the cost effectiveness with which those funds can be accessed. As a result, we do not anticipate that local liquidity restrictions will preclude us from
	funding our targeted expectations or operating needs with local resources. As of December 31, 2016, we had approximately $53.0 million of undistributed earnings in foreign subsidiaries permanently reinvested outside the United States. If we
	distribute our foreign earnings to the U.S. or to other foreign subsidiaries, we could be required to accrue and pay U.S. taxes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our
	liquidity requirements are significant, primarily due to our debt service requirements. In September 2016, ATI completed an offering of $1,000.0&nbsp;million of 5.0% Senior Notes. The 5.0% Senior Notes were offered in a private placement exempt from
	registration under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended. The proceeds from the offering, together with cash on hand, were used to repay $1,200.0&nbsp;million of the Term
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-3
</FONT>
	Loan plus accrued and unpaid
	interest and related transaction expenses. In September 2016, ATI entered into an amendment with the term loan lenders under the Senior Secured Credit Facility to reduce the existing Term
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-3
</FONT>
	Loan commitments
	by $1,200.0&nbsp;million, reduce the revolving credit facility commitments by $15.0&nbsp;million, extend the maturity of the existing Term
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-3
</FONT>
	Loan from 2019 to September 2022 and extend the maturity of the
	revolving credit facility from 2019 to September 2021. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, we had outstanding $1,187.6&nbsp;million of indebtedness associated with ATI&#146;s Term
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-3
</FONT>
	Loan and $1,000.0&nbsp;million
	of indebtedness associated with ATI&#146;s 5.0% Senior Notes. The minimum required quarterly principal payment on ATI&#146;s Term
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-3
</FONT>
	Loan is $3.0&nbsp;million and remains through its maturity date of
	September 2022. There are no required quarterly principal payments on ATI&#146;s 5.0% Senior Notes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our ability to make payments on and
	to refinance our indebtedness and to fund planned capital expenditures will depend on our ability to generate cash in the future. This is subject to general economic, financial, competitive, legislative, regulatory and other factors that may be
	beyond our control. We made net principal payments of $215.2&nbsp;million, $116.5&nbsp;million and $157.6&nbsp;million on our long-term debt for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Senior Secured Credit Facility also provides for a $450.0&nbsp;million revolving credit facility, net of an allowance for up to
	$75.0&nbsp;million in outstanding letters of credit commitments. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, we had $432.2&nbsp;million available under the revolving credit facility, net of $17.8&nbsp;million in letters of credit. Additionally, within the terms
	of the Senior Secured Credit Facility, a senior secured leverage ratio at or below 4.00x results in the elimination of excess cash flow payments on the Senior Secured Credit Facility for the applicable year. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the senior
	secured leverage ratio was 1.53x. The Senior Secured Credit Facility provides certain financial incentives based on our total leverage ratio. A total leverage ratio at or below 4.00x results in a 25 basis point reduction to the applicable margin on
	our revolving credit facility, and a total leverage ratio at or below 3.50x results in a 12.5 basis point reduction to the revolving credit facility commitment fee and an additional 25 basis point reduction to the applicable margin on our revolving
	credit facility. These reductions would remain in effect as long as we achieve a total leverage ratio at or below the related threshold. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the total leverage ratio was 3.08x.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition the Senior Secured Credit Facility and the indenture governing the 5.0% Senior Notes include, among other things, customary
	restrictions (subject to certain exceptions) on our ability to incur certain indebtedness or liens, make certain investments, declare or pay certain dividends, or repurchase shares of our common stock. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, we are in
	compliance with all covenants under the Senior Secured Credit Facility and indenture governing the 5.0% Senior Notes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our credit ratings
	are reviewed regularly by major debt ratings agencies such as Moody&#146;s Investors Service (&#147;Moody&#146;s&#148;) and Fitch Ratings (&#147;Fitch&#148;). In September 2016, our credit ratings were reviewed by Moody&#146;s and Fitch.
	Moody&#146;s held our corporate rating at &#145;Ba2&#146; and assigned &#145;Ba1&#146; to the Term
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-3
</FONT>
	Loan and &#145;Ba3&#146; to the 5.0% Senior Notes. Fitch held our corporate rating at &#145;BB&#146; and
	assigned &#145;BB+&#146; to the Term
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-3
</FONT>
	Loan and &#145;BB&#146; to the 5.0% Senior Notes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	43
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2016, we repurchased approximately $194.5&nbsp;million and $61.7&nbsp;million of our
	common stock under the 2014 Repurchase Program and 2016 Repurchase Program, respectively. All of the repurchase transactions during 2016 were settled in cash during the same period. The 2014 Repurchase Program was completed in November 2016. As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, we had $938.3&nbsp;million available under the 2016 Repurchase Program.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table shows our sources and
	uses of funds for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014 (in millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
